docs.lead_paragraph: SEVERAL weeks ago, a Manhattan resident called a doctor he did not know to say that he was worried about his 83-year-old homebound aunt. She had no doctor of her own (in fact she had not even seen a doctor in 40 years), but she had recently lost a lot of weight. Would he kindly make a house call? What was remarkable about the conversation was not as much the man's request as the doctor's response. He said yes.

headline.main: New Needs of Society Bring Back A Medical Dinosaur: House Calls

docs.abstract: Demand for doctors making house calls is seen growing around country; in New York City, St Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Greenwich Village has seen demand for house calls grow in recent years, as number of elderly people increases, and as their hospital stays decrease as result of insurance restrictions; around country, doctors who did not make house calls now find that they must; experts say it is not only the elderly that are driving doctors to rethink where they practice medicine; it is growing number of AIDS patients as well as children and teen-agers disabled by violence, many of whom want desperately to remain at home (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Mayor Wellington Webb will sign an ordinance extending health insurance to gay partners of city workers in an action that will echo far beyond this city. Four years ago, Colorado voters narrowly approved Amendment 2, a statewide ban on ordinances that barred discrimination against homosexuals. The vote prompted a brief nationwide boycott by gay rights sympathizers, and last spring, the United States Supreme Court ruled the measure unconstitutional.

headline.main: Denver Extends Health Coverage to Partners of Gay City Employees

docs.abstract: Denver, Colo, Mayor Wellington Webb will sign ordinance extending health insurance to gay partners of city workers; action by state's voters four years ago, approving statewide ban on ordinances barring discrimination against homosexuals, noted (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a sign of growing concern about the practices of some health maintenance organizations, 16 states have adopted laws this year to nullify efforts by H.M.O.'s to limit what doctors can tell their patients. Doctors have complained that some H.M.O.'s forbid them to discuss costly treatment options or financial incentives for doctors to withhold care.

headline.main: Laws Won't Let H.M.O.'s Tell Doctors What to Say

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK Siege Leaves Two Dead A gunman obsessed with a teen-aged girl barricaded himself in her family's Brooklyn apartment with a dozen hostages. In a three-hour siege, he shot three captives, pistol-whipped another, then killed his pregnant former girlfriend and himself with bullets to the head. $(Page B1.$) Danielle DiMedici was not yet 17 when she and Mr. Parker began to date. But it took almost no time, officials said, before she virtually disappeared into his world. $(B6.$) Year-Round Classes Weighed Mayor Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said that they would consider keeping the school system open all year to lessen overcrowding. The Mayor and Chancellor were responding to a new report suggesting that the city's finances were so shaky that there would not be enough money soon to house the growing student population. $(B1.$) A student at Bushwick High School in Brooklyn was raped in the school basement, allegedly by another student, in an incident that reignited a dispute over school security. $(B3.$) Clerical workers at Barnard College ended their five-month strike by ratifying a contract in which Barnard gave in to employee demands on health insurance. $(B4.$) No Answers Year After Death Maria Isabel Alves a saleswoman who loved running, swimming and the more mystical side of religion, was killed while jogging on a rainy morning in Central Park one year ago. As the anniversary approached, her mother found herself drawn to her daughter's untouched bedroom in Marica, Brazil, pleading with a picture of Jesus for answers. $(B1.$) Investigators are still seeking the big break they hope will lead them to the man who killed Ms Alves. They remain hopeful that the intense public interest in the case will eventually lead to the clue they need. $(B2.$) With the Mob Went the Mobs There was a familiar hubbub on Mulberry Street as the feast honoring San Gennaro, patron saint of Naples, enjoyed what the Mayor assures us was its first mob-free weekend in a long time. But the fair had that look of faded grandeur Neapolitans know too well. Talk to the vendors, and what you mostly heard was one long lament. Mayor Giuliani stood accused of driving the crowds away. NYC by Clyde Haberman. $(B1.$) East River Ferries Begin East Side commuters took advantage of the first day of ferry service on the East River. ''Finally, a pleasant way to commute,'' said Stephen P. Brooks, a Wall Street investment banker and a resident of the Upper East Side. $(B3.$) Report on City Is Released The annual Mayor's Management Report, a compendium of city statistics required by the City Charter each September, showed that crime and welfare caseloads continued their steep decline in New York City last year, but budget cutbacks combined with a harsh winter to produce a reduction in several critical city services. $(B3.$) Hearings Begin on Helmut Law Skaters and bicyclists banded together at a hearing before the City Council Transportation Committee to criticize proposed laws that would require them to wear helmets or face $50 fines, arguing that the laws would be virtually unenforceable. Police officials, however, testified that the rules would promote safety. $(B3.$) Nassau Chief Plans Tax Cut Nassau County residents would see their property taxes drop by $24 to $38 a year under a $2.2 billion budget proposed by County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta. The budget does not include any major cuts in services, Mr. Gulotta said, but it would reduce the county's 10,000-person work force by 92 positions. $(B5.$) After Graffiti, More Patrols Authorities in Mamaroneck, N.Y., promised stepped-up police patrols after anti-Semitic graffiti was scrawled on two homes in a Jewish neighborhood over the weekend, just as the High Holy Days were beginning. It was the second time in seven months that the neighborhood had been hit. $(B5.$) REGION Airport Security Is Tightened Responding to repeated criticisms of the security at Kennedy International Airport following the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800, Port Authority officials announced a series of immediate changes at all three major airports in the region intended to make it more difficult for anyone to plant a bomb on a plane. The changes range from new lighting and fencing on airport perimeters to the addition of bomb-detecting dogs in terminals, and are intended to tighten access to high-security areas. $(A1.$) No matter how many times authorities investigating the crash of Flight 800 have tried to dismiss the theory that the airplane was destroyed by a missile from an American military craft, it has refused to go away. $(B5.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: After five months on the picket line, clerical workers at Barnard College yesterday ended one of the longest strikes ever at an American college by ratifying a contract in which Barnard gave in to employee demands on health insurance. Ending a strike that embarrassed Barnard's administration and strained the strikers' finances, Barnard agreed to pay all of the workers' health insurance premiums and to allow the workers to remain in their old health care plan.

headline.main: Clerical Workers' Strike at Barnard Ends in Pact

docs.lead_paragraph: Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers union and the Ford Motor Company were guardedly optimistic this evening that they could reach a new national labor contract, as work at factories continued despite expiration of the old contract at midnight on Saturday. While Ford's car and truck assembly lines do not run on Sundays, maintenance workers were on the job today, as were workers at some parts factories with long backlogs. Ford officials said they expected all factories to run normally on Monday.

headline.main: Ford and U.A.W. Optimistic On Reaching an Agreement

docs.lead_paragraph: IN trying to remake the nation's welfare system, members of Congress and President Clinton rarely cite any data or research to support their arguments. And for good reason. The data are skimpy, and on many important questions, the research results are ambiguous, contradictory, confusing or nonexistent.
docs.abstract: Paucity of solid research and accurate data on people who move in and out of welfare system discussed; economist Robert A Moffitt notes that members of Congress want to change behavior of recipients but ignore even the little research that has been done on effects of various incentives (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Just days after Mayor Bill Campbell signed into law a measure to grant health and other benefits to domestic partners of unmarried city employees, opponents filed a lawsuit challenging it as fiscally irresponsible and at odds with the state's recently passed ban on same-sex marriage. The Atlanta ordinance was the second effort in the last three years by people who support the extension of some benefits to the partners of city workers in nontraditional but committed unions. A similar measure, passed in 1993, never went into effect and was overturned in part by the Georgia Supreme Court last year. The new version seeks to overcome the court's objections to the earlier measure's classification of domestic partners as ''a family,'' a classification that the court said could only be granted by the State Legislature.

headline.main: Atlanta Sued Over Its Law On Benefits To the Unwed

docs.lead_paragraph: William Krantz, a 29-year-old chef who lives in Indianapolis, has AIDS and no health insurance. Early this year, as his medical bills began to mount, he applied for a program that was supposed to help people like him get medications. He is still waiting. The program, the AIDS Drug Assistance Program, or A.D.A.P., was established by Congress in 1990 to provide money to states to assist people with AIDS who fall through the cracks of the American health care system. They are not poor enough for Medicaid, the medical insurance program that pays for the drugs and other health care of low-income people. And they either have no insurance or insufficient insurance to buy drugs for themselves.

headline.main: AIDS Patients Slipping Through Safety Net

docs.abstract: Financial pressures beset AIDS Drug Assistance Program, or ADAP, established by Congress in 1990 to provide money to states to assist people with AIDS who fall through cracks of American health care system; they are not poor enough for Medicaid, and they have no insurance or insufficient insurance to buy drugs for themselves; problem is that more and more people are applying for AIDS drug program, encouraged by discoveries that seem keep HIV at bay; at same time, price of AIDS therapy has soared, with more and more drugs added to arsenal; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Virtual Roller Coaster Arrives in Times Square For people who would like to take a roller-coaster ride but are scared of heights, a company called Cinema Ride has the answer: a three-dimensional motion simulator. Cinema Ride opened in Times Square on Monday, in the old Rialto Theater at 1481 Broadway, on the west side of the street between 42d and 43d Streets. Along with the roller-coaster ride, the Los Angeles-based company offers an Atlantis submarine chase scene and an intergalatic flight. A ski and snowboard ride down the slopes of Vail, Colo., will be added to the menu soon. One five-minute ride costs $6; all four will be available for $12. Riders are strapped into a 15-person capsule and fitted with 3-D glasses. Circuit-board decor and black lighting add to the sci-fi atmosphere.
docs.abstract: New Yorkers can now take simulated rides in three dimensions at Cinema Ride on 42d Street; Neighborhood Cleaners Association opens New York office to handle complains about emissions from dry cleaners; strike at the Box Tree Restaurant marks its 1,001st day (M)ï
